p: The intertwined processes of resource extraction, political instability, and food scarcity clearly have a significant impact on why and how people hunt and eat potentially infectious animals (Leach and Hewlett 2010). A few qualitatively inclined studies have extended those insights to explore the social organization of bushmeat markets (Bowen-Jones et al. 2003; Tee et al. 2012) and the specific way ways in which animals are handled, priced, and sold (East et al. 2005; Mendelson et al. 2003; van Vliet and Mbazza 2011; Wilkie and Carpenter 1999). However, these studies are analytically constrained by their normative orientation: Because hunting is understood primarily as a risk to public health (and biodiversity), the symbolic significances, social relations, and affective dimensions of killing, butchering, and eating wild animals are generally left unexplored.
